tn.ref: Heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool
tn.text: Yahweh compares heaven to a throne and the earth to a footstool to emphasize how great he is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Where then is the house you will build for me? Where is the place where I may rest?
tn.text: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize that humans cannot build a place for him to dwell. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Yahweh continues speaking.

tn.ref: My hand has made all these things
tn.text: "Hand" refers to the power and authority of Yahweh, not his physical body. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:14:21|14:22]].

tn.ref: the broken and contrite in spirit
tn.text: Here "broken" and "contrite" refers to a person who is truly humble and who suffers for his faith.
Yahweh continues speaking.

tn.ref: He who slaughters ... also blesses wickedness
tn.text: These four clauses all describe different ways evil people act and come to the same meaning for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: They have chosen their own ways
tn.text: "They have chosen to do evil things that violate the ways of Yahweh"
Yahweh continues speaking about the wicked people.

tn.ref: They did what was evil in my sight
tn.text: Here "sight" refers to Yahweh considering their behavior. AT: "They did what I consider to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Glorify Yahweh" or "May Yahweh glorify himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: but they will be put to shame
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "but I will put them to shame" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Yahweh describes the punishment for the hypocrisy of the worshipers.
The sound represents the real fighting that is going on in the temple as Yahweh is carrying out the punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Yahweh continues speaking.

tn.ref: Before she goes into labor, she gives birth; before pain is upon her, she gave birth to a son
tn.text: Yahweh speaks about Zion as if it were a woman who is about to give birth. Although Zion was destroyed and the people no longer lived there, Yahweh promises that without delay and with little effort an entire nation will come from her. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Who has heard of such a thing? Who has seen such things? Will a land be born in one day? Can a nation be established in one moment?
tn.text: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize how unique this event will be. The series of questions builds tension until Zion is finally mentioned. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Yahweh continues speaking about Jerusalem as if it were a mother. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:isa:66:07|66:7-8]])

tn.ref: Do I bring a baby to the birth opening ... born?
tn.text: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize that he will not fail to fulfill his promises to the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh continues speaking about Jerusalem as if it were a mother and the inhabitants of Jerusalem as if they were newly born children. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:isa:66:07|66:7-8]])

tn.ref: For you will nurse and be satisfied; with her breasts you will be comforted
tn.text: This means Jerusalem will be a place of safety and comfort for God's people. This can be stated in active form. AT: "For she will satisfy you with her milk; she will comfort you with her breasts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Yahweh continues speaking about Jerusalem as if it were a mother. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:isa:66:07|66:7-8]])

tn.ref: like a river ... like an overflowing stream
tn.text: This means God will cause the people of the nations to bring a very large amount of riches, which will be permanent like a river and abundant. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: You will nurse at her side, be carried in her arms, and be dandled on her knees
tn.text: This means Jerusalem will be a place of safety and comfort for God's people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: be carried in her arms, and be dandled on her knees
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "she will carry you in her arms and bounce you on her knees with delight" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: so I will comfort you, and you will be comforted in Jerusalem
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "so I will comfort you in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Isaiah is speaking to God's faithful people.
"Bones" refers to the whole body as a part of it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: will sprout like the tender grass
tn.text: "Tender grass" grows fast and strong and compares to the health and vigor of God's faithful people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: The hand of Yahweh will be made known to his servants
tn.text: Here "hand" refers to his power. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will reveal his power to his servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Isaiah continues speaking to God's faithful people.
Yahweh's appearances in the Old Testament are often accompanied by fire that represents Yahweh's anger and judgment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Storms represent Yahweh's powerful actions to make his judgment effective. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"Sword" is one weapon that represents all of warfare and killing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Those killed by Yahweh will be many
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will kill many people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Isaiah continues speaking.
"They" are those who worship Yahweh but go against his laws.
This is a place where people would go to worship idols. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This describes the leader of those of go to worship idols.
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:14:21|14:22]].
Here "I" refers to Yahweh.
Here "their" refers to the worshipers that are hypocrites whom Yahweh has described before.
These are names of areas that are far from the land of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "they" refers to the foreigners who survived and witnessed to the nations. They will return to Jerusalem with exiled Israelites.
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:11:08|11:9]].

tn.ref: the new heavens and the new earth
tn.text: Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:65:17|65:17]].
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:14:21|14:22]].
Yahweh finishes speaking.
Here "they" refers to all the people, the faithful Israelites and foreigners, who come to worship Yahweh.
Both clauses describe the same idea to emphasize Yahweh's punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
The worms represent the horror of decay and rot that are Yahweh's punishment on the wicked. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Fire also represents Yahweh's judgment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be expressed positively. AT: "will burn forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
This expression represents all created living beings that shrink from the dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
